content.rendered:
It seems that there is always something that can keep us busy. If it’s not work and paying the bills, it’s something else: taking care of others, or just living life.

Staying busy can help pass the time, and help us to forget that our lives may have not turned out exactly as we had hoped. But it can also keep us from discovering some of the more important things that matter not only in this life but in eternity.

The Gospel of Luke tells us a story of how Martha wanted Jesus to tell Mary to help with the meal preparations. Now, Mary was sitting at the feet of Jesus, spending time with him and his disciples. And when Martha asked for help, Jesus said that Mary had chosen something that really mattered.

We may also have times when we will choose between things that will keep us busy, or the things that really matter: our relationship with our God and our relationship with family and friends.

There are going to be times when the need seems so great that we cannot take the time to pray or read the Bible. And we may be too busy working at our jobs or doing things around the house to take spend time with those we love.

Yet, it’s important that we make the time. God though it important enough that He set aside a full day to do nothing but spend time with Him. Opportunities lost may not come around a second time, so it’s important to use the opportunities that we have wisely. Staying busy can be a good thing, but don’t exchange good for what’s best.
